t: Matthew 22
The Parable of the Wedding Banquet
Jesus*p spoke to them again in parables, saying:
“The*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r king*r who*r prepared*r a*r wedding*r banquet*r for*r his*r son.*r
He*r sent*r his*r servants*r to*r those*r who*r had*r been*r invited*r to*r the*r banquet*r to*r tell*r them*r to*r come,*r but*r they*r refused*r to*r come.*r

“Then*rp he*r sent*r some*r more*r servants*r and*r said,*r ‘Tell*r those*r who*r have*r been*r invited*r that*r I*r have*r prepared*r my*r dinner:*r My*r oxen*r and*r fattened*r cattle*r have*r been*r butchered,*r and*r everything*r is*r ready.*r Come*r to*r the*r wedding*r banquet.’*r
“But*rp they*r paid*r no*r attention*r and*r went*r off—one*r to*r his*r field,*r another*r to*r his*r business.*r
The*r rest*r seized*r his*r servants,*r mistreated*r them*r and*r killed*r them.*r
The*r king*r was*r enraged.*r He*r sent*r his*r army*r and*r destroyed*r those*r murderers*r and*r burned*r their*r city.*r
“Then*rp he*r said*r to*r his*r servants,*r ‘The*r wedding*r banquet*r is*r ready,*r but*r those*r I*r invited*r did*r not*r deserve*r to*r come.*r
So*r go*r to*r the*r street*r corners*r and*r invite*r to*r the*r banquet*r anyone*r you*r find.’*r

So*r the*r servants*r went*r out*r into*r the*r streets*r and*r gathered*r all*r the*r people*r they*r could*r find,*r the*r bad*r as*r well*r as*r the*r good,*r and*r the*r wedding*r hall*r was*r filled*r with*r guests.*r
“But*rp when*r the*r king*r came*r in*r to*r see*r the*r guests,*r he*r noticed*r a*r man*r there*r who*r was*r not*r wearing*r wedding*r clothes.*r
He*r asked,*r ‘How*r did*r you*r get*r in*r here*r without*r wedding*r clothes,*r friend?’*r The*r man*r was*r speechless.*r

“Then*rp the*r king*r told*r the*r attendants,*r ‘Tie*r him*r hand*r and*r foot,*r and*r throw*r him*r outside,*r into*r the*r darkness,*r where*r there*r will*r be*r weeping*r and*r gnashing*r of*r teeth.’*r
“For*rp many*r are*r invited,*r but*r few*r are*r chosen.”*r
Paying the Imperial Tax to Caesar
Then*p the Pharisees went out and laid plans to trap him in his words.

They sent their disciples to him along with the Herodians. “Teacher,” they said, “we know that you are a man of integrity and that you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. You aren’t swayed by others, because you pay no attention to who they are.
Tell us then, what is your opinion? Is it right to pay the imperial tax to Caesar or not?”
But*p Jesus, knowing their evil intent, said, “You*r hypocrites,*r why*r are*r you*r trying*r to*r trap*r me?*r
Show*r me*r the*r coin*r used*r for*r paying*r the*r tax.”*r They brought him a denarius,
and he asked them, “Whose*r image*r is*r this?*r And*r whose*r inscription?”*r
“Caesar’s,”*p they replied. Then*p he said to them, “So*r give*r back*r to*r Caesar*r what*r is*r Caesar’s,*r and*r to*r God*r what*r is*r God’s.”*r
When*p they heard this, they were amazed. So they left him and went away.
Marriage at the Resurrection
That*p same day the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him with a question.
“Teacher,” they said, “Moses told us that if a man dies without having children, his brother must marry the widow and raise up offspring for him.
Now there were seven brothers among us. The first one married and died, and since he had no children, he left his wife to his brother.
The same thing happened to the second and third brother, right on down to the seventh.
Finally, the woman died.
Now then, at the resurrection, whose wife will she be of the seven, since all of them were married to her?”
Jesus*p replied, “You*r are*r in*r error*r because*r you*r do*r not*r know*r the*r Scriptures*r or*r the*r power*r of*r God.*r
At*r the*r resurrection*r people*r will*r neither*r marry*r nor*r be*r given*r in*r marriage;*r they*r will*r be*r like*r the*r angels*r in*r heaven.*r
But*r about*r the*r resurrection*r of*r the*r dead—have*r you*r not*r read*r what*r God*r said*r to*r you,*r
‘I*r am*r the*r God*r of*r Abraham,*r the*r God*r of*r Isaac,*r and*r the*r God*r of*r Jacob’?*r He*r is*r not*r the*r God*r of*r the*r dead*r but*r of*r the*r living.”*r
When*p the crowds heard this, they were astonished at his teaching.
The Greatest Commandment
Hearing*p that Jesus had silenced the Sadducees, the Pharisees got together.
One of them, an expert in the law, tested him with this question:
“Teacher, which is the greatest commandment in the Law?”
Jesus*p replied: “ ‘Love*r the*r Lord*r your*r God*r with*r all*r your*r heart*r and*r with*r all*r your*r soul*r and*r with*r all*r your*r mind.’*r
This*r is*r the*r first*r and*r greatest*r commandment.*r
And*r the*r second*r is*r like*r it:*r ‘Love*r your*r neighbor*r as*r yourself.’*r
All*r the*r Law*r and*r the*r Prophets*r hang*r on*r these*r two*r commandments.”*r
Whose Son Is the Messiah?
While*p the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,
“What*r do*r you*r think*r about*r the*r Messiah?*r Whose*r son*r is*r he?”*r “The*p son of David,” they replied.
He*p said to them, “How*r is*r it*r then*r that*r David,*r speaking*r by*r the*r Spirit,*r calls*r him*r ‘Lord’?*r For*r he*r says,*r
“ ‘The*rpn Lord*r said*r to*r my*r Lord:*r “Sit*rld at*r my*r right*r hand*r until*rln I*r put*r your*r enemies*r under*rld your*r feet.” ’*r
If*rp then*r David*r calls*r him*r ‘Lord,’*r how*r can*r he*r be*r his*r son?”*r
No one could say a word in reply, and from that day on no one dared to ask him any more questions.
